It was kind of a strange explanation so here’s the basics of how it works. Lots of people use analogies but they get confusing.

A company can sell a part of itself called a share. The purpose of this is mainly for the company to raise money for itself.
If the company does well and it’s worth doubles, now your $1 share is worth $2. Of the company does bad and it’s worth halves, your $1 share is worth $0.50. Think of a share like in the show shark tank where the company owner offers to sell X% of his company for X amount of money. The company owner does it for to raise funds.

Everyone in the world is able to buy and sell shares, and anyone can use an app/brokerage to do so. People are generally able to buy and sell shares whenever they want in basically any volume as well.

There are other factors that influence share price as well, like how many people buy or sell their shares of that company. If a ton of people sell shares all of a sudden the shares value drops and vice versa. There’s a ton of ant factors as well

All of these factors are combined in an algorithm which assigns a price to the shares in real time, and this algorithm is what creates those graphs of a companies stock.

When you sell a share it will be sold to anyone in the world who is willing to buy it for that price. Or it can go to the brokerage who keeps a stockpile of shares for itself to sell to its other customers (I believe).

So a regular “retail” trader (non-professional) will do a ton research to find companies that have a likely upwards or downwards trend in price. They will then buy shares of a company they think will do well. For example the trader bought 100 shares at $10 each. They spent $1000. The company grows (or some other event happens) and then the price of the stock goes up to $50 a share. The trader can now sell his 100 shares for $5000 and they just made $4000.

Traders can also use something called a put-option to actually make money if the stock price goes down, but that’s a little more complicated.

Another explanation can be done by looking at the origin of stocks:

Dutch colonial expeditions made a lot of money, but they also needed a lot of money to send, they needed men a boat and a captain, so they would sell shares of the profit from the expedition to people, the person would buy “shares” in the voyage, the money they payed goes towards the expedition costs, while they get a percentage of profit about equal to the amount of the expedition they payed for, the modern stock market is this today but with every business and shares can be exchanged between traders, shares grow in value as the business grows, since they are essentially a part of the business being owned by the trader.

I don't think you mentioned the fact that a share entitles you to a share in a company's profits, which is really where its value comes from. This seems to be focusing on speculative investing which is not all that the stock market is about.

Not to mention, you directly linked the "value" of a company and its share price, which is an oversimplification. A company and its stock are valued by the market, and the way the market decides to price a share is to look at the future expected profits of a company (because that's what you're going to be getting out of it if you own shares and thus are entitled to a share of profits). Of course, speculators are less bothered about this as they don't typically hold shares long enough to receive any dividends.They just want to know if the share price will be up next week/month.

i think a crucial point about stocks has been skipped. That's the reason why stocks where created in the first place. Why would I as the owner of a company would want to issue shares and therefore spread my earnings amongst a broad group of people? because what shares do is spread the risk around. If my bussiness is doing good, everybody wins and yes, i wouldn't win 100% of those earnings since there are other people who own portions fo the company, but even then i can just go to the stock exchange and re buy my own shares. But what happens if things go south? well i would lose only a fraction of what i'd lose if i didin't issue the shares in the first place, if i kept it all for myslef, i would have lost it all! Also, current enterprises require massive ammounts of money to be set up and to operate. I can´t wait until i start getting revenue to raise the capital, it's the other way around, and issuing shares is a way to accrue that capital AND spread the risk both at once. If you want to thank ( or blame) anyone for this creation, that would be the dutch. One of the first publicly traded companies in history was the dutch east india company which was, by many accounts, the most prosperous and wealthy corporation in history. They lasted for hundreds of years (and yes they engaged in A LOT of nasty practices) but during those prosperous times, anybody in Holland could be a partial owner of that money making machine. In the end they lasted for over 218 years and their net worth at it's peak is around 8 TRILLION dollars in today´s money, that's roughly 50% of the GDP of the USA!

While this video is rather old, there is a huge amount of misinformation in the comments that seem to be confusing people even further.

When a company wants to raise money to further their operations, they have a few different options. They can go to the bank and ask for a loan that they eventually have to pay back, or they can issue stock in their company. Each stock represents a small piece of ownership in the company. So when a company issues stock, they are essentially selling a piece of their company to investors, and in turn use the money from the sale to expand their business. Companies often issue many millions of shares of stock.

When you want to buy stock in a company, you will buy it from a stock exchange, which is a centralized place where people go to buy and sell shares of a company. Now, what determines how much a stock will cost? In short, its supply and demand based on what you and other investors believe that piece of the company to be worth. If you look at the financials and determine that a share of Company A is worth $10, and you can find someone that will sell you their share in Company A for $10, then that share is worth $10 on the stock exchange. When you buy the share, you hope that the company will continue to do well, both financially and socially, and other people that are buying and selling shares in the company on the stock exchange will value them even higher, and that the share price will grow even higher.

Once you determine that you are ready to sell your shares (for any number of reasons), you go back to the exchange to sell your shares. When selling your shares, it works the exact same as when you purchased it. If you believe that the price of shares of Company A that you have been holding are now worth $20, and you can find someone that also believes they are worth $20, then you can sell your share through the exchange. Now that you have sold the share for $20, you have made a profit of $10 on Company A stock ($20 you sold it for - $10 you paid for it = $10 profit)!

In regards to dividends, they are separate of stock price. When a company does particularly well in a given quarter and after funding their business operations they have extra profits left over, they can choose to share those profits with their share holders. So they will give a set amount per share held to their share holders, which is a dividend. Not all companies do this, they are not required to, however many that do often have their share price go up because investors take this as good news that the company is doing better than expected. This doesn't happen all the time, but many times it has.

This explanation is poor. Let me try to explain it to those who are confused - when a corporation goes public (i.e. gets listed on a stock exchange and it's owned partially by the public), they conduct an IPO (initial public offering). This is the only time that the corporation will obtain money from the shares, unless they buy them back and/or reissue them. Once investors buy these IPOs, they can they sell them again to the rest of the public on the stock exchange. This is the secondary market, and this is where normal people like us buy shares. The corporation does not actually benefit monetarily from these trades unless they own some of these shares.

I'd like to add a few points:
-Share prices in the market reflect (most of the time) what the MARKET thinks the company is worth, not what the company is ACTUALLY worth.
-This is where security valuation comes to play where people (usually analysts) try to estimate the value of a company and buy/sell the security based on whether it is under or overvalued.
-If the market actually reflected the worth of companies then nobody would trade because the share price would already accurately reflect the worth of the company, thus eliminating the potential for any kind of profit.

If you treat shares as lottery tickets, you will get what this video says - gambling, and an unknown result.  However, you should buy company shares because you feel the value of the shares is worth more than your money.  You buy shares, because you want to own a piece of the company, more than your cash - and you would do that because you feel the company will be worth more in the future, while in the meantime, your cash decreases in value due to inflation.  You are trading your cash for assets, not gambling to buy and sell.

Donkey, I saw you question on how the stock exchange works. I couldn't reply because I couldn't see the reply link, strangely on only your comment. There is technically no minimum. You can buy 1 share if you have the funds and hopefully start earning returns on that. The problem with this is, you aren't diversified and you can incur large commission charges. Depending on the broker, some brokers charge per trade, regardless of the number of shares. Common advise, is to first invest in a mutual fund which usually have a minimum of $500. There are usually is no upfront, back end fees, but there are usually trailer fees of 0.5%-3% that incur yearly. The best benefits are, your $500 would be highly diversified and there is trained active management. Once you saved up to a recommended amount of $10,000, and are a somewhat knowledgeable investor, then it's recommended to diversify into stocks and/or bonds. This way the commissions on buying shares yourself are usually lower than the trailer fees of a mutual fund, as long as you're not actively trading. Depending on your risk tolerance, expect to earn 3%-10%.

This really is not a very informative video if you want to learn about stocks, since it paints the stock market as a place you go to for gambling your money on the short term and does not mention important things such as stock dividends which are the whole point of owning stock.

Stocks are by far the best long term investment you can make, as long as you see stocks as a paper that gives you dividends from a company, and the market only as a place to buy or sell them and nothing more. If you feel that you have to react to events quickly or even bother about the short term value of your stock, you are using stocks the wrong way. You should judge the price of a stock by the dividends and capital that it's company holds, not by how the market price has been trending recently.

@NikiHerl A healthy and profitable company will usually increase in value BECAUSE people see value in it and buy it. Thus the two are not directly but indirectly linked quite strongly. In fact this is the strategy of Warren Buffet : buy healthy profitable companies, and as you can see it's worked quite well for him. Problem is when the company becomes big their stock price doesn't change much and it's pretty hard to find a healthy, profitable, and smaller company.

@MartinWinters You own a piece of the company. When the company makes money, the stock becomes more valuable. When the stock has more bang for the buck, more people demand it so the price increases and you make money.
